message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is caused by defects in the synthesis, structure, or processing of collagen. Type V collagen is the most common type associated with the classic subtype of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Impaired copper absorption is associated with Menkes disease. Defective type III collagen is associated with vascular type Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Defective type I collagen is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including easy bruising, skin fragility, and joint laxity, suggest a connective tissue disorder. Among the options, only defective type V collagen is associated with a connective tissue disorder called Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Impaired copper absorption is associated with Menkes disease, while defective type III collagen is associated with vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Defective type I collagen is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is caused by defects in collagen production. Among the options, only defects in type V collagen are associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Impaired copper absorption is associated with Menkes disease and defective type III collagen is associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV. Defective type I collagen is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and among the options, only defective type V collagen is associated with this condition. Impaired copper absorption is related to Menkes disease, Defective type III collagen is related to Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV, and Defective type I collagen is related to osteogenesis imperfecta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including easy bruising and fragile skin, suggest a connective tissue disorder. Among the options, only defective type V collagen is associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which can cause joint hypermobility and fragile skin. Impaired copper absorption is associated with Menkes disease, defective type III collagen is associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV, and defective type I collagen is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a connective tissue disorder and among the options, only defective type V collagen is related to Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents as easy bruising, joint hypermobility, and fragile skin. Impaired copper absorption is related to Menkes disease, which presents with similar symptoms but also has neurological symptoms like seizures. Defective type III collagen is related to vascular type Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which has additional symptoms like arterial and organ ruptures. Defective type I collagen is related to osteogenesis imperfecta, which presents with brittle bones and blue sclera.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is caused by defects in collagen. Type III collagen is specifically associated with the type of EDS that presents with easy bruising and joint hypermobility. Therefore, the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms is defective type III collagen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), and among the options, only defects in type V collagen are associated with EDS. Impaired copper absorption can cause Menkes disease, which also involves connective tissue problems, but it presents differently. Defective type III collagen is associated with the rare Ehlers-Danlos syndrome types IV and V, which typically do not involve joint hypermobility. Defective type I collagen is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). Among the options, only defective type V collagen is associated with EDS. Impaired copper absorption is associated with Menkes disease. Defective type III collagen is associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, type IV. Defective type I collagen is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is caused by a defect in collagen production. Among the options, only defects in type V collagen are associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Impaired copper absorption is associated with Menkes syndrome, a rare disorder that affects copper levels in the body. Defective type III collagen is associated with vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Defective type I collagen is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.
